Deep Learning in Natural Language Processing

Language: en Complexity: Beginner

Natural Language Processing (NLP) is an important part of many real world applications used by most people in our society today. Most prominent examples are automatic machine translation, search engines, or speech recognition. In this talk I will give a short overview over existing NLP applications and the challenges they still face. Following that, I will show the application of deep learning techniques to two important NLP tasks: language modelling and sentiment analysis.

Sebastian Ebert PhD Student, Chair for NLP, LMU

Sebastian is a PhD Student at Hinrich Schütze's Lab at Ludwig Maximilian University Munich. His research is about Sentiment Analysis, Deep Learning and Neural Language Models.

Deep Learning in Computer Vision

Language: en Complexity: Beginner

Classification and detection are still major problems in computer vision and waiting to be addressed. Recent studies in deep learning show an outstanding performance in these tasks. Deep learning methods are representation learning methods which allow a machine to learn the representations of data with multiple levels of abstraction. In this talk, I will discussthe major advantages of deep learning methods in computer vision applications by focusing on Convolutional Neural Networks and recent works, including our latest research 'FlowNet: Learning Optical Flow with Convolutional Networks'.

Caner Hazırbaş PhD Student, Chair for Computer Vision, TUM

Caner received his Computer Engineering Bachelors Degree at Yildiz Technical University, Istanbul and Informatics Masters Degree at the Technical University, Munich (TU München). During his study, he focused on object recognition and detection in the fields of computer vision and machine learning. He is currently pursuing a Ph.D. at the Computer Vision Group, TU Munich under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Daniel Cremers. He is interested in deep learning, object detection/recognition, semantic scene understanding.

Welcome to Deep Learning in Action

Language: en

David Dao Graduate Student Researcher, Exelixis Lab, HITS

ACM IEEE Computer Society

David is a M.Sc. Student at TUM and a Student Researcher at Heidelberg Institute for Theoretical Studies (HITS). Before his studies, David worked as intern at CERN. For his thesis he will work on machine learning at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. He is interested in machine learning and its applications, including bioinformatics, computer vision, natural language processing and information retrieval

Causative Adversarial Learning

Language: en Complexity: Intermediate

Modern learning systems rely more and more on real-world data, which is booming up in many kinds of applications. A bundle of machine learning algorithms and applications are therefore developed to fit the highly demanding intelligent agents. However,are they really reliable systems? Are the learning algorithms themselves not in a danger of being fooled by their intrinsic algorithmic flaws? In this talk, we share some ideas from the adversarial perspective to spot some of the weakness in the trend ofmachine learning algorithms and introduce a new rising research line in the machine learning community. We kindly expect theawareness of the adversarial side of learning systems and invoke researchers and practitioners’s consideration while they design the learning systems.

Huang Xiao PhD Student, Chair for IT Security, TUM

Huang is a PhD Student at the IT Security Chair at TUM. His research includes adversarial learning theory, robust learning, semi-supervised learning, nonparametric learning, and other general machine learning methods.
